title.narrative: Improving knowledge about climate change and resilience in Central America

description.narrative: This project was designed using assessments of recently-completed CAFOD projects in the ‘dry corridor’ of Central America, including El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua. Central America is a high-risk region for natural disasters due to its geographic position – earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, hurricanes, recurrent floods and droughts are prevalent. Weather hazards in the region are expected to become more extreme and less predictable due to climate change. The project locations are typically unproductive for cattle and crop farming, yet this is the only land that poor subsistence farmers can access. A very limited variety of crops such as sorghum, beans and corn can be grown in this dry environment. This project is part of CAFOD’s long-term commitment to partners in Central America to invest in supporting communities to understand and mitigate against environmental risks and shocks – not just for example sudden onset floods, volcanic eruptions and earthquakes, but also ongoing environmental hazards such as access to water, crop failure and lack of access to fertile land. The project will contribute to raising awareness about natural resources, promoting care of natural resources, especially amongst local authorities, and investing financial resources in renewable energy to generate new income for poor communities. The following effects of climate change at the local level were identified in consultation with partners at the end of 2016: - Loss of harvests in staple grains, vegetables, etc. - Pests and diseases mainly in maize, beans and other crops, - Loss of drinking water sources (springs, rivers, wells, creeks, wetlands, etc) - Loss of homes, livestock - Damage to health
